review.title: A Hierarchical Emotion Regulated Sensorimotor Model: Case Studies
review.abstract: Inspired by the hierarchical cognitive architecture and the perception-action model (PAM), we propose that the internal status acts as a kind of common-coding representation which affects, mediates and even regulates the sensorimotor behaviours. These regulation can be depicted in the Bayesian framework, that is why cognitive agents are able to generate behaviours with subtle differences according to their emotion or recognize the emotion by perception. A novel recurrent neural network called recurrent neural network with parametric bias units (RNNPB) runs in three modes, constructing a two-level emotion regulated learning model, was further applied to testify this theory in two different cases.

sections.heading: 3.1 Parametric Bias
sections.text: Recurrent Neural Network with Parametric Bias Units [19, 20, 28, 27, 26] (Fig. 2) is a family of recursive neural networks consisting of an additional bias unit that acts as bifurcation parameters for nonlinear dynamics. In other words, the adjustable values in such a small number of units can determine different dynamics in the network with large dimensions. As these units differ from ordinary bias, they are trained by the training sequences with backpropagation over time (BPTT) in a self-organizing manner, so that the units exhibit differences in the characteristics of the training sequences. Furthermore, the parametric bias units (PB units) give the network, as bifurcation parameters for nonlinear functions, the ability to learn various nonlinear dynamic attractors, making it advantageous compared to generic recursive networks. Based on the above features, an RNPB network can be considered a two-layered network based on the two-layered structure.

sections.heading: 3.2 Three Modes
sections.text: The RNPB three running modes in an RNPB network, i.e. learning, detection and generation modes. They functionally simulate different stages between sensorimotor sequences and high internal states of these sequences. The neural dynamics and algorithms of these modes are as follows: • Learning mode (fig. 3a): The learning algorithm works offline and supervises the internal values in PB units. When providing the training impulse with a new pattern, the weights that connect neurons are updated with BPTT (back propagation over time). Furthermore, the residual errors from the BPTT are updated the internal values in PB units; the internal values of the PB units are updated in a self-organizing manner by this error, which is derived from the backward propagation.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Recognition Mode
sections.text: The detection mode is executed with a similar information flow to the learning mode: In a series of spatio-temporal sequences, the error between the target and the real output is propagated back through the network to the PB units. However, the synaptic weights remain constant and only the PB units are updated, so that the PB units are self-organized according to certain epochs as pre-trained values. sections.text: The values of the PB units can also be set manually or determined by detection, so that the network can generate the coming sequence with a single-stage prediction. In addition, according to [8], a trained RNPB can not only retrieve and detect different types of pre-learned nonlinear oscillation dynamics as an extension of the memory capacity of working memory within the sensory system, but also adds the generalizing ability to detect and generate non-linear dynamics and compositions.

sections.heading: 5 Summary
sections.text: This hierarchical architecture is based on the perception model, in which the inner state (emotion) acts as a precursor in the feedback pathways to further modulate perception and action. Following the proposed two Bayesian conclusions between the internal state and sensorimotor behavior, we propose to use a recursive neural network of parametric bias units (RNPB) to construct a two-tiered architecture in which the parametric bias represents an internal state. Nonverbal generation of expressions and demonstrations of emotion recognition testify to the feasibility of this hierarchical architecture. In the next steps, a few possibilities can be created to further expand this architecture: 1) more factors such as goal, perception from previous states and knowledge can be considered, 2) a more complex hierarchical learning method can be used to extract and generate hierarchical hierarchies more strongly.
